article_title: Ad wars replace face-to-face campaigns in District 23
article_text:
Ad wars replace face-to-face campaigns in District 23

Photo: William Luther / San Antonio Express-News The Editorial Board recommends Pete Gallego for reelection to the...

SAN ANTONIO — To hear the TV announcers tell it, the race for U.S. House District 23 pits two guys who don't respect veterans or the elderly.

article_metadata.description: SAN ANTONIO — To hear the TV announcers tell it, the race for U.S. House District 23 pits two guys who don't respect veterans or the elderly.  Even the candidates squirm over those brutal portrayals of one another in one of the nation's costliest and most competitive congressional races.  With early voting starting today, both campaigns and advocates are saturating airwaves with clashing portrayals of the first-term incumbent and his brash challenger.  Gallego, an attorney and former Texas House member who's been stymied in the “do-nothing” Congress, faces a serious challenger in Hurd, 37, a former CIA agent and cybersecurity specialist who has a network of supporters as a former student body president of Texas A&M University.  The 23rd District, one of the nation's largest, covers a quarter of the U.S.-Mexico border, extending to the edges of San Antonio and El Paso and everything in between — parts of the Eagle Ford Shale, farm and ranch land, arid Southwest Texas and the Big Bend.  The district, which may be redrawn soon because of redistricting litigation, poses logistical challenges for candidates, but more importantly for voters who increasingly rely on TV ads for their candidate information rather than personal contact.  Upon taking office in 2013, Gallego was targeted for defeat by the National Republican Congressional Committee, and he's now in the cross hairs of several conservative groups that have come to Hurd's side after initial indications that the race wasn't winnable for the GOP.  [...] Gallego, 52, still may have an edge as voting nears, but the anti-Gallego ads are having some effect, and there's even a silver lining for Hurd in the anti-Hurd ads, the Republican candidate said.  Relying on web and TV ads, Hurd has used a “have you heard” theme, introducing him as a fiscal conservative tired of Washington gridlock and specially equipped by his CIA experience to deal with national and border security.
article_metadata.author.name: By John W. Gonzalez, San Antonio Express-News
